clustersPage.alert: There are no active environments.  You will need to create or activate one before you can do anything else.
clustersPage.subtext:
{appName} supports grouping resources into multiple clusters and environments.

Environment: A namespace where applications, services, and containers are defined. The containers in an environment can communicate with each other over a shared managed network, and different users/groups can be given access to manage the resources of the environment.

Cluster: A group of physical (or virtual) compute resources. Each environment is tied to one cluster and will run all its containers on cluster's hosts, and a cluster can be shared with more than one environment.

For example, you might create a "production" cluster for each team in your company with bare-metal hosts and a single dedicated environment with restricted access, and a shared "sandbox" cluster with shared virtual machines that any employee can use to create their own isolated dev & test environments.

advanced.detail: Direct requests to different services based on port, Host header, or request path
advanced.help1:
If Request Host and/or Path are specified, connections to HTTP listening ports will be routed to the appropriate target based on the request.
For example, you could use this to send traffic for domain1.com to a different service than domain2.com, or domain3.com/admin to a different service than domain3.com.
advanced.help2:
Matching requests will be sent to the Target Service on the Target Port.
If that is not set, then the Default Target port for the Source Port.  If that is also not set, then the Source Port.

startFirst.detail: Start new containers before stopping the old ones.  If the service publishes a port, there must be enough eligible hosts availeble to run Batch Size new containers, because the old containers are still actively using the ports.
startFirst.label: Start new, then stop old

stopFirst.detail: Stop the old containers (up to the Batch Size), then start new ones.  This allows the reuse of published ports.  Adjust Batch Size to ensure that you keep enough active capacity to run your application.
stopFirst.label: Stop old, then start new

formUpgrade.title: Upgrade Policy

setup.prefix: Multiple server containers can be deployed on different hosts so that {appName} keeps running even if one of the hosts fail.
setup.suffix: for information on setup and usage.

commercial.content: At Rancher Labs we provide commercial, enterprise-grade support for {appName}, including an available 24x7 support team, and priority bug fixes. In addition we provide implementation, integration and consulting services for organizations looking to implement and scale {appName}. For more information on any of these services, please email our sales team: sales@rancher.com

environment.content:
{appName} supports grouping resources into multiple environments. Each one gets its own set of services and infrastructure resources, and is owned by one or more GitHub users, teams or organizations.

For example, you might create separate "dev", "test", and "production" environments to keep things isolated from each other, and give "dev" access to your entire organization but restrict the "production" environment to a smaller team.

host.content:
Before adding your first service or launching a container, you must add at least a single Linux host that supports Docker {minVersion} or higher and be able to reach the {appName} server via HTTP. {appName} supports adding Linux hosts in the form of a virtual or physical
    machine from any public cloud providers, privately hosted clouds, or even bare metal servers.

graphic2.link:
about using {appName} Visit our docs.
or check out our getting started documentation.

content.paragraph1: {appName} is an open source software platform that implements a purpose-built infrastructure for running containers in production. Docker containers, as an increasingly popular application workload, create new requirements in infrastructure services such as networking, storage, load balancer, security, service discovery, and resource management.

A service is simply a group of containers created from the same Docker image but extends Docker's "link" concept to leverage {appName}'s lightweight distributed DNS service for service discovery. Services can be added individually or by deploying an item from the Catalog.
content.paragraph2: A service is also capable of leveraging other {appName} built-in services such as load balancers, health monitoring, upgrade support, and high availability.

dashboard.content: A Kubernetes irányítópult egy általános célú, web alapú felhasználói felület a Kubernetes fürtökhöz. Lehetővé teszi a felhasználóknak hogy alkalmazásokat kezeljenek a fürtben és hibaelhárítást végezhessenek, valamint kezelhessék magát a fürtöt.

stepOne.generateConfigText: To use kubectl (v1.4+ only) on your workstation, click the button to generate an API key and config file:

accessConfig.subtext1: Enter the address, port, and protocol to connect to your {providerName} server. 389 is the standard port for insecure, 636 for TLS.
accessConfig.subtext2: {appName} needs a service account that has (read-only) access to all of the domains that will be able to login, so that we can determine what groups a user is a member of when they make a request with an API key.

userSearchBase.helpText: Only users below this base will be used.

confirmDisable.post: Biztos vagy benne?  Kattints újra, hogy valóban letiltsd a hozzáférés-szabályozást

disable.warning: Caution: Disabling access control will give complete control over {appName} to anyone that can reach this page or the API.

accessEnabled.subtext: To change the server configuration, disable access control below and then set it up again.

customizeSchema.helpText: If your schema does not match the standard ActiveDirectory format, you can customize it here.

disabled.label: {providerName} is not configured
disabled.warning: {appName} can be configured to restrict access to a set of {providerName} users and groups.  This is not currently set up, so anybody that reach this page (or the API) has full control over the system.

enabled.label: {providerName} engedélyezve van
enabled.unrestricted: {appName} is configured to allow access to any {providerName} user.

agentIp.label: Specify the public IP that this host should register as.  If left empty, Rancher will auto-detect the IP to use.

detail.firewall: The host agent initiates a connection to the server, so make sure firewalls or security groups allow it to reach the URL in the command.
detail.ip: The IP address to register the host with typically will be detected automatically.
detail.manual: If the host is behind a NAT or the same machine that is running the {rancherImage} container you may need to explicitly specify the IP to use in the advanced section below.
detail.networking: All hosts in the environment will also need to allow traffic between each other for cross-host networking

driverCustom.instructions: Copy, paste, and run the command below to register a host running a supported version of Docker with {appName}. The host should pop up within a minute.

windows.step1: Start up a Windows Server 2016 machine somewhere and install the latest version of Docker on it.
windows.step3: Copy, paste, and run the command below in PowerShell to start the {appName} agent.

Rancher Labs szeretne névtelen információkat gyűjteni a telepítésed beállításairól hogy jobbá tudja tenni a {appName} alkalmazást.
Az adataid nem lesznek megosztva senki mással és a konkrét erőforrás nevét vagy címét sem gyűjtik össze.
